case_data.chief_complaint: Recurrent kidney stones, bone pain, and generalized fatigue for 8 months
case_data.initial_presentation: A 42-year-old government clerk from Lucknow presents with recurrent bilateral kidney stones (3 episodes in 8 months), diffuse bone pain in the lower back and legs, and progressive fatigue. He was referred from urology after his third episode of renal colic, with the urologist noting persistently elevated serum calcium levels on routine workup.

stages.info: Patient reports 3 episodes of renal colic in 8 months — bilateral, calcium oxalate stones confirmed on analysis. Diffuse bone pain in lumbar spine, bilateral tibiae, worsening over 6 months. Generalized weakness and fatigue limiting work. Increased thirst and polyuria for 4 months (urine output ~3-4 L/day). Constipation — chronic, worsened recently. Loss of appetite with 4 kg unintentional weight loss. Occasional nausea. Mild depressive symptoms (low mood, poor concentration) noticed by wife. No history of fractures. No neck swelling noticed. No family history of kidney stones or endocrine disorders. No lithium use. No excessive calcium or vitamin D supplementation. No history of malignancy, tuberculosis, or sarcoidosis. He takes pantoprazole occasionally for dyspepsia. Non-smoker, occasional alcohol.

Mild dehydration (dry tongue, reduced skin turgor). No pallor or jaundice. BMI 23. Neck examination: No visible or palpable thyroid nodule. No cervical lymphadenopathy. However, a small (1 cm) firm, non-tender nodule is palpable just inferior to the left lobe of thyroid on deep palpation (possible parathyroid adenoma — rarely palpable, but an atypical finding). Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over lumbar spine and bilateral tibiae on palpation. Proximal muscle weakness — grade 4/5 in hip flexors bilaterally. Abdomen: Mild bilateral renal angle tenderness. No hepatosplenomegaly. No band keratopathy on slit lamp (later confirmed). Cardiovascular: Short QT interval suspected clinically — confirmed on ECG.

Serum calcium (total): 13.2 mg/dL (elevated; normal 8.5-10.5). Ionized calcium: 1.72 mmol/L (elevated; normal 1.12-1.32). Serum albumin: 4.0 g/dL (normal — corrected calcium also elevated). Serum phosphorus: 1.8 mg/dL (low; normal 2.5-4.5). Intact PTH: 285 pg/mL (markedly elevated; normal 10-65 — inappropriate elevation in setting of hypercalcemia confirms primary hyperparathyroidism). Alkaline phosphatase: 380 U/L (elevated; normal 44-147). 24-hour urine calcium: 420 mg/day (elevated; >250 in males — rules out FHH). Calcium/creatinine clearance ratio: 0.025 (>0.02, supporting PHPT over FHH). Serum 25-OH Vitamin D: 12 ng/mL (deficient — common in Indian patients, can worsen bone disease in PHPT). Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL (mildly elevated). BUN: 28 mg/dL. ECG: Shortened QT interval. USG neck (Tc-99m Sestamibi scan): Single focus of increased uptake inferior to left thyroid lobe on delayed images — consistent with left inferior parathyroid adenoma. USG abdomen: Bilateral nephrocalcinosis with 8mm calculus in right renal pelvis. X-ray hands: Subperiosteal bone resorption along radial aspect of middle phalanges (pathognomonic). X-ray skull: Salt-and-pepper appearance (pepper pot skull). DEXA scan: Osteoporosis — distal 1/3 radius T-score -3.1 (cortical bone preferentially affected in PHPT).

case_data.diagnosis: Primary Hyperparathyroidism due to left inferior parathyroid adenoma with symptomatic bone disease (osteitis fibrosa cystica) and nephrolithiasis
differentials: Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid adenoma — most common cause)
Vitamin D-mediated hypercalcemia (granulomatous disease — sarcoidosis, tuberculosis)
Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN1 or MEN2A) with hyperparathyroidism
learning_points: Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is diagnosed by the combination of hypercalcemia with inappropriately elevated or non-suppressed PTH. The most common cause (~85%) is a single parathyroid adenoma.

Classic mnemonic for hypercalcemia symptoms: 'Stones (nephrolithiasis), Bones (osteitis fibrosa cystica), Groans (abdominal — constipation, nausea, pancreatitis), and Psychic Moans (depression, confusion, fatigue)'. Indian patients often present with advanced bone disease due to concomitant vitamin D deficiency.

Calcium/creatinine clearance ratio >0.02 differentiates PHPT from FHH — this is critical before surgery. FHH is benign and does NOT require parathyroidectomy. 24-hour urine calcium >250 mg/day also supports PHPT.

Subperiosteal bone resorption (radial aspect of middle phalanges), salt-and-pepper skull, and brown tumors are radiological hallmarks of osteitis fibrosa cystica in severe PHPT — seen more frequently in the Indian population compared to the West due to delayed diagnosis and coexistent vitamin D deficiency.
case_data.atypical_features: This case is challenging because: (1) the patient presented primarily through urology for recurrent stones, requiring the student to connect nephrolithiasis with a systemic endocrine disorder; (2) coexistent severe vitamin D deficiency (common in India) has exacerbated the skeletal manifestations, producing florid osteitis fibrosa cystica — a presentation now rarely seen in Western countries but still encountered in India; (3) a palpable parathyroid nodule is unusual and may mislead towards a thyroid pathology; (4) the mild renal impairment and hypertension add complexity to management decisions; (5) the student must distinguish PHPT from FHH using urinary calcium excretion and calcium/creatinine clearance ratio before recommending surgery.
